articles.headline: New Evidence in Ethiopian 737 Crash Points to Connection to Earlier Disaster
articles.snippet: A piece of equipment found at the crash site suggests that the jet may have had a problem with a new flight-control system that is also suspected in the Lion Air crash.
articles.abstract: A piece of equipment found at the crash site suggests that the jet may have had a problem with a new flight-control system that is also suspected in the Lion Air crash.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investigators at the crash site of the doomed Ethiopian Airlines flight have found new evidence that points to another connection to the earlier disaster involving the same Boeing jet.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Thomas Kaplan and James Glanz

articles.headline: Two New Zealand Mosques, a Hate-Filled Massacre Designed for Its Time
articles.snippet: The horror, meant for an era that has married social media with racism, was motivated by white extremist hatred, streamed live on Facebook and calculated to go viral.
articles.abstract: The horror, meant for an era that has married social media with racism, was motivated by white extremist hatred, streamed live on Facebook and calculated to go viral.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wounded tried to crawl away or lie still, while others ran or crouched behind the dead, but the gunman kept pulling the trigger.

articles.headline: Wall Street Has Been Unscathed by MeToo. Until Now.
articles.snippet: Sara Tirschwell alleges her boss pressured her into sex. He denies it. Now discovery is underway on her $30 million lawsuit.
articles.abstract: Sara Tirschwell alleges her boss pressured her into sex. He denies it. Now discovery is underway on her $30 million lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 14, 2017, Sara Tirschwell was called into an unscheduled meeting with the general counsel and chief compliance officer of her employer, the giant asset-management firm TCW. Ms. Tirschwell, 53, was an experienced investor who had been hired the previous year to raise and run a new distressed debt fund for TCW. Entering the conference room, high above Midtown Manhattan, she wasn’t sure what the meeting was about. It didn’t take long for her to find out: She was being fired.

articles.headline: As Costs Skyrocket, More U.S. Cities Stop Recycling
articles.snippet: With China no longer accepting used plastic and paper, communities are facing steep collection bills, forcing them to end their programs or burn or bury more waste.
articles.abstract: With China no longer accepting used plastic and paper, communities are facing steep collection bills, forcing them to end their programs or burn or bury more waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: Recycling, for decades an almost reflexive effort by American households and businesses to reduce waste and help the environment, is collapsing in many parts of the country.

articles.headline: She Extols Trump, Guns and the Chinese Communist Party Line
articles.snippet: Cindy Yang once owned the Florida massage parlor where Robert Kraft was arrested in a prostitution sting. Now she promises access to the president and raises money for him.
articles.abstract: Cindy Yang once owned the Florida massage parlor where Robert Kraft was arrested in a prostitution sting. Now she promises access to the president and raises money for him.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — The Republican National Committee promised an “evening reception with Donald J. Trump” last March at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Fla.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, Michael Forsythe and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: ‘God Is Testing Us’: Tears and Outrage at a New Zealand Hospital
articles.snippet: Some at the attacked mosques had come from places scarred by war; others had grown up in Christchurch. But they all came together to seek answers at a hospital.
articles.abstract: Some at the attacked mosques had come from places scarred by war; others had grown up in Christchurch. But they all came together to seek answers at a hospital.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — The families drifted from the mosques to the hospital, their emotions battered, their eyes bloodshot.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Jamie Tarabay

articles.headline: After 2 Crashes of New Boeing Jet, Pilot Training Now a Focus
articles.snippet: When the 737 Max was introduced, Boeing and regulators agreed that pilots who had flown an earlier model didn’t need additional simulator training.
articles.abstract: When the 737 Max was introduced, Boeing and regulators agreed that pilots who had flown an earlier model didn’t need additional simulator training.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Boeing backed down on Wednesday. He called President Trump to recommend that the United States temporarily take the company’s best-selling jet out of service, following two deadly crashes in less than five months. Hours later, the president announced that the plane had been grounded.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff, David Gelles, Jack Nicas, Thomas Kaplan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: After Mosque Massacre, New Zealand Has Its Gun-Debate Moment
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern had made clear that lawmakers will look at a range of options, from gun buybacks to restrictions on magazines for semiautomatic rifles.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern had made clear that lawmakers will look at a range of options, from gun buybacks to restrictions on magazines for semiautomatic rifles.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — When the prime minister announced plans to ban semiautomatic rifles following Friday’s mass shootings, it seemed to be the bold response that many New Zealanders wanted — until the country’s attorney general backpedaled almost immediately and said that might not be the government’s final decision.

articles.headline: ‘It Is Unspeakable’: How Maduro Used Cuban Doctors to Coerce Venezuela Voters
articles.snippet: President Nicolás Maduro sent doctors door-to-door to warn the ill and elderly that care would be cut off unless they voted for the governing party, said 16 Cuban physicians who worked in Venezuela.
articles.abstract: President Nicolás Maduro sent doctors door-to-door to warn the ill and elderly that care would be cut off unless they voted for the governing party, said 16 Cuban physicians who worked in Venezuela.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yansnier Arias knew it was wrong. It violated the Constitution, not to mention the oath he took as a doctor in Cuba.

articles.headline: Boeing Black Box Data Shows Similarities Between Ethiopian and Lion Air Crashes
articles.snippet: Information from the recorders on an Ethiopian Airlines jet that crashed is similar to findings from an earlier crash of a 737 Max, officials said.
articles.abstract: Information from the recorders on an Ethiopian Airlines jet that crashed is similar to findings from an earlier crash of a 737 Max, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — A preliminary review of the “black boxes” recovered from a jetliner that went down in Ethiopia found similarities between that crash and one involving the same Boeing model in Indonesia five months earlier, Ethiopia’s transport ministry said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Selam Gebrekidan, James Glanz and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: U.S. Campaign to Ban Huawei Overseas Stumbles as Allies Resist
articles.snippet: The Trump administration’s effort to ban Huawei from overseas wireless networks has suffered from questions over whether the Chinese telecom company poses a threat.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration’s effort to ban Huawei from overseas wireless networks has suffered from questions over whether the Chinese telecom company poses a threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s aggressive campaign to prevent countries from using Huawei and other Chinese telecommunications equipment in their next-generation wireless networks has faltered, with even some of America’s closest allies rejecting the United States’ argument that the companies pose a security threat.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: Quick Action, Near Miss and Courage in New Zealand Attacks
articles.snippet: A bystander and police preparedness may have helped limit the toll by a gunman equipped to inflict far greater damage.
articles.abstract: A bystander and police preparedness may have helped limit the toll by a gunman equipped to inflict far greater damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — Abdul Aziz was praying with his four sons in the Linwood Mosque when he heard the gunshots. Rather than run from the noise, he ran toward it, grabbed the first thing he could find — a credit card machine — and flung it at the attacker.

articles.headline: Why a Big Tech Breakup Looks Better to Washington
articles.snippet: Antitrust is the nuclear bomb of regulatory moves, but at a moment when nearly everything in America seems contentious, proposals to break up internet giants are gaining support.
articles.abstract: Antitrust is the nuclear bomb of regulatory moves, but at a moment when nearly everything in America seems contentious, proposals to break up internet giants are gaining support.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A decade ago, when the greed and carelessness of the financial industry came close to destroying the American economy, the overwhelming response by politicians and the public was: Meh. Almost instantly, all was forgiven and forgotten.

articles.headline: It Wasn’t Just Khashoggi: A Saudi Prince’s Brutal Drive to Crush Dissent
articles.snippet: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman created a secret team that spied on, kidnapped and tortured Saudi citizens a year before the journalist was killed.
articles.abstract: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman created a secret team that spied on, kidnapped and tortured Saudi citizens a year before the journalist was killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia authorized a secret campaign to silence dissenters — which included the surveillance, kidnapping, detention and torture of Saudi citizens — over a year before the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, according to American officials who have read classified intelligence reports about the campaign.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Apple’s Big Spending Plan to Challenge Netflix Takes Shape
articles.snippet: The tech company, about to have a showcase event on its campus, is expected to reveal details about a dozen or more programs ready to go or almost done.
articles.abstract: The tech company, about to have a showcase event on its campus, is expected to reveal details about a dozen or more programs ready to go or almost done.

articles.headline: Investors Eagerly Await Trump Rules on Opportunity Zones
articles.snippet: Potentially billions of dollars are waiting on the Treasury’s decision on rules that will help determine how many new businesses sprout in Opportunity Zones, a creation of the Trump tax law.
articles.abstract: Potentially billions of dollars are waiting on the Treasury’s decision on rules that will help determine how many new businesses sprout in Opportunity Zones, a creation of the Trump tax law.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVONDALE, Ariz. — A hotel groundbreaking ceremony here in an old cotton field not far from Interstate 10 last month featured two United States senators, a hot catered lunch and a stream of speeches about driving economic investment to this corner of the Southwest that is still recovering from the Great Recession.

articles.headline: ‘Pied Piper’ of College Admissions Scam Had All the Answers
articles.snippet: Rick Singer built a national brand appealing to parents’ worries about their children’s college prospects. He said he had the secrets to admission.
articles.abstract: Rick Singer built a national brand appealing to parents’ worries about their children’s college prospects. He said he had the secrets to admission.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was part coach, part therapist, part motivational speaker and part name dropper. Like a traveling salesman, he sought out clients near and far, selling dreams of prosperous futures.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Serge F. Kovaleski and Jose A. Del Real

articles.headline: Medicare for All Is Divisive (in the Democratic Party)
articles.snippet: Democrats are at odds over how to fulfill their promise to lower health costs, with centrists opposing the “Medicare for all” plan favored by progressives.
articles.abstract: Democrats are at odds over how to fulfill their promise to lower health costs, with centrists opposing the “Medicare for all” plan favored by progressives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No issue animated the Democrats’ 2018 congressional campaigns like health care and the promises to expand access to insurance and to lower costs. But as House Democrats sit down to draft their vision of governance in the coming weeks, lawmakers find themselves badly divided on the issue that delivered their majority.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Women in Economics Report Rampant Sexual Assault and Bias
articles.snippet: Survey findings are prompting the profession’s leaders to take action to prevent sex discrimination and physical abuse of female economists.
articles.abstract: Survey findings are prompting the profession’s leaders to take action to prevent sex discrimination and physical abuse of female economists.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly 100 female economists say a peer or a colleague has sexually assaulted them. Nearly 200 say they were the victim of an attempted assault. And hundreds say they were stalked or touched inappropriately, according to a far-reaching survey of the field.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
